553 508 Pd-catalyzed amination 626
554 508 Pd-catalyzed amination 626

The reaction of SubPs with electrophilic reagents is another route to functionalize the meso-positions. meso-LithioSubPs can be generated by bromine-lithium exchange of bromo-SubP derivatives such as 508 through treatment with n-Buli at 98 C. The resulting organolithium species can be trapped with different electrophiles, such as benzophenone, DMF, CO2, chlorotrimethylsilane, N-fluorobenzenesulfonimide and mesitylboryl fluoride, giving rise to the corresponding meso-functionalized SubPs 546552 (Table 22).631

meso-Nitro SubPs 555 and 556 were prepared by nitration reaction of meso-free SubPs 429 and 445 with AgNO2 and I2 and were reduced to meso-amino SubPs 557 and 558 with NaBH4 and Pd/C, respectively (Scheme 48).606,632


Scheme 48 meso-Amino SubPs 557 and 558.

Some meso- and peripheral substituents may be cyclized at the adjacent position to afford fused SubPs. For example, SubP 560 bearing a fused thiochromane has been prepared from meso-2-bromophenylsulfanyl-substituted SubP 559 by intramolecular Pd-catalyzed CH activation reaction (Scheme 49).628 A related SubP 564 (Scheme 49) bearing a fused pyran ring has been synthesized in 14% overall yield by cleavage of the methoxy group of SubP 431 with BBr3, giving a hydroxy group, followed by perbromination and intramolecular ether formation in the presence of potassium carbonate.633 Similarly, SubP 562, containing two fused dihydroquinoline rings, has been obtained by a double cyclization of the aryl groups in the ,-diiodo-meso-diarylamino subporphyrin SubP 561. The latter entails a radical-nucleophilic substitution reaction (SRN1) involving stable radical intermediates that are generated by single electron transfer from tert-butoxide or diarylamide anions to the SubP, with concomitant loss of iodide ions of 561.634


Scheme 49 SubPs with fused heterocycles at the meso,-positions.

A few cyclometalated subporphyrin complexes wherein the metals are coordinated either to the meso- or the -pyrrole positions have been reported. The former are constituted by the NCN-type pincer complexes 565 and 566 (Fig. 103) that have been prepared by metalation of the meso-free 486 with palladium and platinum salts, respectively,618 as well as the earring complex 567,635 which has been obtained by treatment of the corresponding meso-free ligand with Pd(OAc)2.


Fig. 103 Structures of pincer (565 and 566) and earring (567) meso-metallated SubPs, and -pyrrole metalated SubPs 568 and 569.

When the meso-position is substituted with a 2-pyridine ligand such as SubP 545, iridium complexation takes place by treatment with [Cp*IrCl2]2, producing CH activation of the adjacent pyrrole -positions to give a mixture of regioisomers 568-exo and 568-endo in a 72/28 ratio.593 Likewise, Ir(III) metalation of the corresponding trispyridyl-SubP 408 proceeds quite cleanly, producing exclusively C3-symmetric SubP 569.593

6.2.2 Reactivity at the axial position. Most of SubPs are reported as methoxo-compounds that are obtained by treatment with MeOH, as one of the last steps in the synthesis of SubPs. This contrasts with axial ligand exchange reactions of SubPcs, which typically require more forcing conditions.68 The axial hydroxo- or methoxo-groups can easily be replaced by any other alkoxy or carbonyloxy groups, for different purposes, for example, to obtain single crystals that can be studied by XR diffraction,586 or to endow the molecule with additional functionalities, such as a thiol group.636 This process can be reverted to the axial hydroxy SubP by simply washing the B-alkoxy and B-carbonyloxy subporphyrin with aqueous HCl. Interestingly, bowl-inversion has been observed in some SubPs containing a chiral sulfinyl substituent at one of the -positions, upon treatment with alcohols at different temperatures. The latter strongly suggests the formation of a borenium cation intermediated SN1-type mechanism for axial exchange reactions in protic solvents.613

As for subazaporphyrins,159 fluoro-substituted SubPs are prepared by treatment of the hydroxo-form with BF3OEt2 (Scheme 50).610,637 Both alkoxylation and fluorination reactions occur in quantitative yields and are reversible under acidic conditions. Fluoro-substituted SubPs are quite less polar than the corresponding hydroxo-SubPs, providing an alternative tool, complementary to the methoxo-substitution, for their isolation.


Scheme 50 Fluoride substitution of SuPs at their axial positions.

SubPs bearing a BC bond are prepared in 6090% yields by reaction of the corresponding methoxo-SubPs with excess Grignard reagents (Scheme 51 and Table 23, methods A and B),606,638 or in 5080% yields by treatment with the less nucleophilic arylzinc reagents (method C).639 The latter allows the axial substitution with functional groups that are not compatible with conditions of methods A and B, such as nitrile, ketone, ester, or halogens. The axial substituents may be further manipulated by standard organic chemistry, constituting an excellent platform, complementary to meso and peripheral substitution, to endow the SubPs with additional properties, such as in compounds 592596 (Fig. 104), obtained in one step from compounds 588, 589 and 590, respectively.626,639 Methods AC constitute an interesting and versatile alternative to the previously reported method D (Table 23) involving the intermediation of a borenium cation.640


Scheme 51 Axial functionalization with BC bonds.
Table 23 Axial substituents involving BC bonds introduced in SubPs
SubP Ar1 Ar2 R Methoda Ref.
a Method A: RMgBr (20 equiv.), dioxane, reflux. Method B: TMSCl (20 equiv.), RMgBr (20 equiv.), THF, 0 C. Method C: TMSCl (20 equiv.), RZnI, THF, rt. Method D: 1-Et3Si[CH6B11Br6]; 2-PhLi, cyclohexane/ether, toluene. b RMgBr (2 equiv.), toluene, 0 C.
574 Ph Ph A 638
574 Ph Ph D 640
575 Ph Ph A 638
576 Ph Ph A 638
577 Ph Ph A 638
578 Ph Ph A 638
579 Ph Ph A 638
580 Ph Ph A 638
581 Ph Ph A 638
582 Ph Ph A 638
583 Ph Ph A 638
584 Ph Ph A 638
585 Ph Ph Et A 638
586 H B 606
587 H B 606
588 Ph Ph C 639
589 Ph Ph C 639
590 Ph Ph C 639
591 Ph Ph C 639


Fig. 104 SubPs prepared by Grignard treatment of 588 followed by hydrolysis (592), hydrolysis of 589 (593), SuzukiMiyaura coupling on 590 (594) and Pd-catalyzed amination reactions on 590 (595 and 596).

SubP B-hydrides 597599 have been prepared in moderate to very good yields by reaction of methoxo-SubPs with DIBAL-H.641 The hydride 597 can be hydrolyzed to give hydroxo-SubP 389, or used in hydroboration reactions of aldehydes and imines, affording the corresponding alkoxo- and amino-SubPs 600 and 601 (Scheme 52).


Scheme 52 Generation, hydrolysis and hydroboration reactions of SubP-hydrides.

Axial peroxides 602604 have been synthesized by treatment of methoxo-SubP 390 with hydrogen peroxide, tert-butyl peroxide, and MCPBA, respectively, in fairly good yields (Scheme 53). Subsequent heating of the peroxide 602 gave peroxo-bridged subporphyrin dimer 605 in 97% yield.642 This reactivity of 602 contrasts with that of 389 and may be ascribed to higher nucleophilic character of the B-hydroperoxide moiety. In addition, dimer 605 was stable towards hydrolysis, contrasting with the corresponding SubP -oxodimer that was quickly hydrolyzed in the presence of water. Peroxides 603 and 604 did not undergo similar thermal dimerization, suggesting that the formation of 605 may involve nucleophilic trapping of a borenium cation intermediate.


Scheme 53 Formation of SubP peroxides.

6.3 Characterization of subporphyrins

6.3.1 Single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Almost all the structures of key SubPs have been revealed by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. SubP 415 shows a curved and conical structure, similar to those of all the other subporphyrinoids, with BN and BO distances of 1.501.51 and 1.44 , respectively, and a bowl-depth of 1.51 (Fig. 105).595 The latter characterizes the degree of curvature of SubPs, which is defined by the distance from the mean plane of the peripheral six -pyrrolic carbons to the central boron atom. Compared to SubPzs (1.76 bowl-depth) and SubPcs (2.55 bowl-depth),76 the conical structure of SubPs is considerably shallower.159
Fig. 105 X-ray crystal structures of SubPs 415 and 390. (a) Top view and (b) side view of 415. (c) Top view and (d) side view of 390. Thermal ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level. Adapted with permission from ref. 2 and 595. Copyright 2018 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim. Copyright 2007 American Chemical Society. (e) Substituent labelling for SubPs Table 24.

As a general trend, the curvatures for substituted SubPs are slightly smaller than that of unsubstituted SubP 415, and depend on the axial, meso- and -substituents, as well as crystal packing manners. Thus, for example, introducing one (SubP 606), or two (SubP 430) phenyl substituents at one or two of the meso-positions slightly flattens the molecule to bowl depth values of 1.42 and 1.46 , respectively, while the curvature of the corresponding triphenyl-substituted SubP 390 is of 1.29 (Table 24 and Fig. 105). Comparable effects are observed upon trialkyl (SubP 491)586 or bis ethoxycarbonyl (SubP 437) meso-substitution.603 Functionalizing at the six -pyrrole positions with ethyl groups (SubP 412) or fusing benzene rings at the same positions (BzSubP 387) also reduces the SubP bowl depths (1.43 and 1.32 , respectively). The corresponding meso-triphenyl-substituted SubPs 411 and 388 are still shallower (1.16 and 1.18 , respectively), reflecting the smaller curvatures of SubPs fully substituted at both meso- and -positions (see Table 24 SubPs 411, h, 457, 459, 455, 460, 461, 462, 463 and 388). In this respect, compound 461, containing three meso-phenyl substituents and six tert-butylsulfanyl groups at the -positions, shows a curvature of 1.04 ,611 which represents the smallest bowl-depth among all the reported neutral SubPs.

Table 24 Selected structural data of SubPs from X-ray analysis
SubP R1 R2 R3 R4 X Bowl-depth () i (deg) BX () Ref.
a Angles i (i = 1, 2, 3) are defined by the dihedral angle between the plane of CCmesoC and the mean plane of the meso-ring (a range flanked by the narrowest and the widest angles is provided). b Obtained after conversion into the OCOCF3-derivative. c Obtained after conversion into the 3,5-dinitrobenzoyloxy-derivative. d Substituted at the meso-positions with 3,5-di-tert-butylphenyl rings. e Obtained after conversion into the OMe derivative. f Obtained after conversion into the 3-chloro-benzoyloxy-derivative. g Obtained after conversion into the triphenylsilyloxy-derivative.

606 Ph H H H OMe 1.42 38.140.5 1.44 595

557 Ph Ph NH2 H OMe 1.44 46.952.5 1.46 632

411 Ph Ph Ph Et OMe 1.16 71.788.6 1.45 594

457 3,5-(t-Bu)2C6H3 3,5-(t-Bu)2C6H3 3,5-(t-Bu)2C6H3 Ph OMe 1.22 64.681.9 1.45 609
459 3,5-(t-Bu)2C6H3 3,5-(t-Bu)2C6H3 3,5-(t-Bu)2C6H3 OMe 1.24 69.979.5 1.44 609
454 Ph Ph Ph OMe 1.28 68.976.6 1.43 609
460 Ph Ph Ph 4-MeOC6H4S- OMe 1.28 80.484.5 1.43 611
461 Ph Ph Ph t-Bu-S OMe 1.04 60.171.9 1.45 611
462 Ph Ph Ph Ph-S OMe 1.30 67.780.7 1.44 611
463 Ph Ph Ph OMe 1.36 66.978.1 1.43 611
387 H H H OMe 1.32 1.43 7
388 Ph Ph Ph OSiPh3 1.18 57.883.7 1.41 581
585 Ph Ph Ph H Et 1.41 44.649.2 1.61 638
574 Ph Ph Ph H Ph 1.42 48.063.3 1.61 640
597 Ph Ph Ph H H 1.35 41.450.4 1.26 641
570 Ph Ph Ph H F 1.29 42.749.7 1.41 641
389 Ph Ph Ph H OH 1.37 41.651.9 1.44 642
602 Ph Ph Ph H OOH 1.24 38.644.0 1.47 642
603 Ph Ph Ph H OO-t-Bu 1.31 42.448.4 1.45 642
604 Ph Ph Ph H 1.28 41.252.0 1.49 642
390 Ph Ph Ph H 1.28 43.448.4 1.51 642

Differently, SubPs contain fused rings involving both meso-and -positions, such as 562 (Scheme 49), or the corresponding metallacycles 568 and 569 (Fig. 103), are forced to take large bowl depths of around 1.63, 1.52 and 1.56 , respectively.593,634

A distinctive feature of SubPs with respect to their triaza-SubPc and SubPz congeners, and even to the corresponding porphyrins, is the strong interaction produced by the meso-aryl substituents with the aromatic SubP core and hence, stronger influence of these substituents on the macrocyclic electronic properties. meso-Phenyl SubPs 606, 430, 390, 508, 585, 597, 570, 637, 602, 603 and 604 lacking -substituents (Table 24) display relatively small dihedral angles that range only between 38.152.0, contrasting with those of 5,10,15,20-tetraarylporphyrins, which usually exhibit larger dihedral angles (>60). Substitution of the meso-rings at para- or meta-positions (SubPs 397 and 407, respectively) produce SubPs with similar dihedral angles (Table 24). However, meso-aryl groups containing ortho-substituents, like in 399 and 418 (Table 24), show larger dihedral angles (61.079.0) due to the steric hindrance of the ortho-substituents,2,584 these effects being even larger (7882) for the corresponding porphyrins.643 Other aromatic meso-rings such as thienyl- (SubP 401) or pyridyl (SubP 166) also display small dihedral angles allowing their strong electronic conjugation with the SubP core. On the opposite side are fully substituted SubPs such as 411, h, 459, 454, 460, 461, 462, 463 and BzSubP 388, which are sterically congested and so, accommodate the meso-aryl substituents almost perpendicular to the SubP core, exhibiting larger dihedral angles of 64.6084.5. Remarkably, the dihedral angles between the SubPs and the terminal aryl groups with the arylalkynyl- or the arylvinyl-groups (compounds 513, 512 and 454; Table 24) are considerably small, running from 14.6 to 31.6, and indicating extended conjugation through the vinyl and ethynyl linkers.601,609

The aromaticity of SubPs is manifested in their crystal structure by the little bond length alternation in the macrocycle, although the situation for their aromatic substituents may be different. meso-4-Aminophenyl-substituted SubPs 493 and 496 (Fig. 102), for example, show a quinonoid-type bond alternation,1,573,599 in addition to low dihedral angles (41.258.6 for 493 and 42.748.6 for 496), indicating strong interactions between the meso-(4-aminophenyl) substituent and the SubP core.573,600

SubPs 523, 524 and 543 (Table 22), bearing one primary arylamino group directly attached to one of the meso-positions, show strong electronic interaction between the arylamino substituent and the SubP core.625,630 In these cases, -donation from the amine to the SubP produces a resonance structure in which the CmesoN distances become shorter. This is reflected in the crystal structures of these compounds as seen by the unusually short CmesoN distances of 1.393, 1.374 and 1.365 , respectively (1.4021.417 for usual CN bonds). Likewise, SubPs 536, 537 and 538 (Table 22) containing a secondary diarylamino moiety exhibit CmesoN bond lengths that are shorter than CipsoN bond lengths, suggesting a double bond character as well, which increases in the order 536 < 537 < 538 in accordance with the donor character of the diarylamino group.628 The shortest CmesoN distance (1.347 ) is observed for SubP 557 bearing a primary amine directly attached to the meso-position.632 Conversely, for 4-nitrophenylamino-substituted compound 525 (Table 22) the CmesoN distance is of 1.405 , while CipsoN distance is of 1.379 . The latter is thought to reflect a higher contribution of a resonance structure in which the meso-nitrogen is -donating to the benzene ring owing to the presence of the nitro electron-attracting substituent.625

Similar effects are observed in meso-alkoxy substituted SubP 527, wherein CmesoO distance is of 1.455 , while CipsoO distance is of 1.265 .627 The corresponding thioether 531, however, exhibits almost identical CmesoS and CipsoS distances (1.761 and 1.764 , respectively), reflecting the significantly lower donor character of the sulfur atom.627 On the other hand, when the nitrogenated meso-substituents are pyrrole, indole or carbazole derivatives (SubPs 540542) the CmesoN bond lengths significantly increase to 1.4211.430 , suggesting much weaker or negligible electron-pair donating interactions of the meso-substituents.628meso-Nitrated SubPs 555 and 556, on the other hand, exhibits an even longer CmesoN distance of 1.4311.436 .606,632

With respect to -substitution, nitro and amino-SubPs 475 and 476 (Scheme 43), display short CN bond lengths of 1.399 and 1.336 , respectively, indicating strong interaction with the SubP ring.612 Besides, the CS distances in -substituted hexasulfanyl-SubPs 461 and 462 show slightly shorter values of 1.7501.759 related to the corresponding CipsoS distances (1.7721.790 ).611,613

6.3.2 Rotational dynamics of meso-aryl-substituents. The rotational dynamics of SubP meso-substituents has been examined2,609 and previously reviewed.1meso-Aryl substituents of SubPs have lower rotational barriers. Since the SubP convex and concave faces are nonequivalent, the rotation of meso-phenyl groups can be studied by 1H-NMR spectroscopy. Thus, for example, meso-(3,4,5-trimethoxyphenyl)-SubP 398 displays the same chemical shift for Hexo and Hendo protons, as diagnostic of fast rotation of the meso-aryl substituents in the 1H-NMR timescale. In contrast, even at 130 C, meso-(2,4,6-trimethoxyphenyl)-SubP 399 exhibits different signals for its corresponding Hexo and Hendo protons, indicating a larger rotational barrier of the meso-aryl groups. The coalescence temperatures and (GROT) of the meso-aryl substituents for SubPs h, 454459 have been previously determined.609

More recently, the rotational dynamics of SubPs 431, 432, 433, 434, and 435 have been studied by VT 1H-NMR spectroscopy. In order to lower the rapid rotational barrier, the corresponding axially substituted SubP-Ph derivatives were prepared using phenylmagnesium bromide.

In the 1H-NMR spectrum of 431 at 20 C, the signals of the 2-methoxy protons are observed as two separate broad signals that sharpen at 40 C, appearing at 4.04 and 3.53 ppm with a 56:44 ratio. These peaks have been assigned to the Hexo- and Hendo-protons of the corresponding atropisomers, respectively,602 which were found to coalesce at 35 C. The rotation rate constant of the 2-methoxyphenyl group at each temperature has been estimated to be of 13, 340, and 4000 s1 at 20, 20, and 60 C, respectively. From these rate constants, the activation parameters of the rotation of the 2-methoxyphenyl group in 431 have been determined and the same method has been applied for the other SubPs. A comparison of the rotation activation parameters of 431435 revealed variable contributions of H and S to G with the following consequences:

(1) The rotational barriers of SubP-Ph derivatives are smaller than those of SubP-OMe species.

(2) Ethoxy (190) and isopropoxy groups (433) exert similar G298 values, which are larger than that of a methoxy group (431); among 432 and 433, the rotation of the 2-isopropoxy aryl group occurs via a pre-ordered transition state with less enthalpic cost.

(3) Alkyl group in 435 restricts the rotation of the meso-aryl groups much more than alkoxy groups.

(4) The chloro group at the 4-position in SubP-Ph 434 does not influence the rotational dynamics. However, good -electron donor groups such as amino groups tend to lower G298, probably due to electronic stabilization of the coplanar rotation transition state.

The rotational dynamics of meso-substituents in SubPs -substituted with thioethers has also been studied.6111H-NMR studies indicate that the meso-phenyl substituents undergo restricted rotation for 460463. Besides, the -sulfanyl substituents are conformationally flexible in arylsulfanyl 460 and 461, as well as benzodithio-SubP 463, while are strictly regulated to an anti-conformation in the tert-butylsulfanyl-SubP 462.

6.3.3 Optical properties. SubP 415 displays a Soret band at 341 nm arising from a transition that is analogous to the B transition of porphyrins within Gouterman's four-orbital model. In addition, a vibronic structure appears as two absorption bands at 432 and 455 nm with an order of magnitude less intense than the B band (Fig. 106), which correspond to Q-like transitions within Gouterman's four-orbital model.644 The Soret-like band of SubPs is progressively red shifted upon substitution at the meso-positions with phenyl rings, and the same occurs for the Q-absorptions. Thus, SubPs 606, 430 and 390 (Table 25) exhibit their corresponding B-bands at 352, 362 and 373 nm, respectively, while the Q-bands appear at, 440 and 461, 450 and 461, and 484 nm, respectively, indicating electronic interaction of the meso-phenyl groups with the SubP core. The latter has been attributed to smaller steric hindrance around the meso-phenyl groups in SubPs related to the corresponding tetraphenylporphyrins,595 which leads to a substantial electronic conjugation of the aromatic meso-rings to the SubP core in meso-phenyl and thienyl-SubPs 390 and 421, contrasting with porphyrins, for which this conjugation is only marginal.
Fig. 106 Normalized UV-vis absorption (a) and fluorescence (b) spectra of 415, 606, 430, and 390 in CH2Cl2. Adapted with permission from ref. 595. Copyright 2018 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

The normalized fluorescence spectra of 415, 606, 430, and 390 are shown in Fig. 106b, revealing emission bands between 450 and 600 nm that have been assigned to S1 fluorescence. Upon sequential addition of meso-phenyl rings the fluorescence spectra show red-shift, with the fluorescence bands mirroring the respective Q-like bands, and Stokes shifts gradually higher of 150, 550, 780, and 880 cm1, respectively.595 When going from 415 to 390 the fluorescence quantum yields (F) decrease, while the fluorescence lifetimes (F) become elongated in the order 415 = 390 < 606 < 430.

Interestingly, a different fluorescence profile has been observed for 390 at 380450 nm upon excitation at the B-band at about 350410 nm (Fig. 107). This fluorescence has been assigned to S2-to-S0 (S2) fluorescence because it is a mirror image of the S2S0 absorption.575 The observation of the dual fluorescence for SubP 390 indicates that these molecules do not obey Kasha's, rule, maybe due to a large energy gap between the S1 and S2 states of SubPs. -Hexaethyl SubP 411 does not show any discernible S2 emission, while the corresponding meso-unsubstituted SubP 412 does it upon excitation at its Soret band.594


Fig. 107 Ground-state absorption and static fluorescence spectra of SubP 390 in toluene. ex = 370 nm. The asterisk (*) indicate Raman peak of the solvent. Absorption; S2 emission; S1 emission. Adapted with permission from ref. 575. Copyright 2013 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

As a general trend, any functionalization of the SubP skeleton at the meso- and/or -positions cause red shifts both at B and Q absorption bands with respect to the unsubstituted 415 (Fig. 109a). The only exceptions to this rule are constituted by meso-trifluoromethyl-substituted SubP 419 and -ethyl-substituted SubP 412, as specified below. Typically, SubP derivatives display their B-band in the 340380 nm region and their Q-band in the 400540 nm region (Table 25). Therefore, absorptions of SubPs lie at considerably shorter wavelengths (ca. 3050 and 70100 nm, respectively) than the corresponding bands of the metallated tetraphenylP (ca. 410420 and 500610 nm). This blue shift arises from the smaller -electronic circuit of SubPs (14-electrons) related to Zn(II)tetraphenylP (18-electrons). Besides, the absorption coefficient of the SubP Soret band is ca. 25% that of Zn(II)tetraphenylP in the same solvent.2,3 The smeared vibronic structure in Q-like absorption and broad fluorescence bands seem to arise from the bowl-shaped SubP core in contrast to the comparatively flat structure of Zn(II)tetraphenylP (Fig. 108).3


Fig. 108 Steady-state absorption (solid lines) and fluorescence (dashed lines) spectra of Zn(II)tetraphenylP (black) and 390 (red) in toluene. Reproduced with permission from ref. 2. Copyright 2007 American Chemical Society.

SubPs usually exhibit green fluorescence in a range of 470670 nm with the main peak observed in the 508543 nm region (Table 25). Stokes shifts are in a range of 7002950 cm1 and fluorescence quantum yields are larger than those of Zn(II) tetraphenyl porphyrins (Fig. 109).


Fig. 109 UV/Vis absorption (black) and fluorescence (red) spectra in dichloromethane (solid line) or methanol (dashed line), and calculated transition (blue bar) by TD-DFT method at the B3LYP/6-31G* level of (a) 409, (b) 399 and (c) 397. Adapted with permission from ref. 2. Copyright 2007 American Chemical Society.

meso-Alkyl substituents also shift the absorption bands to the red (360, 450, 472 nm) in 491, although in lesser extent than triphenylation. The Stokes shift value is also small (489 cm1), probably reflecting a smaller radiative chromophore size. A similar effect is observed upon substitution with two carboxylic esters at the meso-positions in SubP 437 (362, 476, 505 nm).603 However, an electron withdrawing alkyl chain such as the trifluoromethyl-derivative 419 causes the opposite effect, with a Soret band at 341 nm, similar to that of unsubstituted SubP. In this case, however, Q-bands are red-shifted to 443 and 473 nm. The fluorescence spectrum of 419 is also a mirror image of the Q bands, exhibiting the most intense band at 482 nm, while the fluorescence quantum yield is quite small.596

SubP 399, bearing hindered 2,4,6-trimethoxyphenyl meso-substituents, represents the second group. This SubP with restricted rotation of their meso-aryl substituents exhibits the Soret band at 372 nm and only one band at 454 nm in the Q-region,1,609 while the fluorescence band appears at 524 nm with a shoulder at 500 nm (Fig. 109). Other SubPs with only one Q-band, or with a very weak Q00 component, bear non-hindered meso groups such as 2-, 3- or 4-pyridyl (408, 393 and 391, respectively),2,593 and p-trifluoromethylphenyl-substituents (394) (Fig. 110).571 It has been suggested that electron-donating groups can give rise to more intense Q00 components than electron-withdrawing groups such as 2-, 3-, or 4-pyridyl, pentafluorophenyl, or trifluoromethylphenyl.2,571,584,593 In agreement with this consideration, 391 displays the weakest Q00 component, while the Q-band of 493, bearing strong -electron donor amines, appears as a broad absorption at 510 nm, showing the largest increase of the Q00/Q01 ratio (Fig. 110).573 However, the complete rationalization of the optical spectra is more complex, as p-nitrophenyl-meso substituent shows completely different behavior in this respect,2 and axial substituents produce notable alterations in the energy and intensity of the two transitions (see for example Table 25 and ref. 1).593


Fig. 110 (a) Q-band region of SubPs bearing meso-aryl groups of different nature in CHCl3. Adapted with permission from ref. 571. Copyright 2007, American Chemical Society. (b) UV-vis absorption and emission spectra of 493. Adapted with permission from ref. 573. Copyright 2009 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

4-Nitrophenyl-substituted SubP 397 represents the third type, displaying a bathochromically shifted Soret-band at 400 nm and a Q-band in which the Q00 and Q01 components have comparable intensities (Fig. 109).2

As seen for the absorption spectra of meta-substituted SubPs 402 and 492 that are almost identical to those of 390,8 the electronic influences of the meta-nitrophenyl and meta-aminophenyl substituents are almost negligible. Differently, para-nitrophenyl and para-aminophenyl meso-substituents exert remarkable red shifts both in the absorption and fluorescence spectra. While the mesopara-nitrophenyl substituent reduces the fluorescence quantum yield, the mesopara-aminophenyl substituent intensifies the quantum yield.573 As evident in Table 25, these tendencies can be considered as a general behavior of SubPs containing conjugated nitrophenyl and aminophenyl substituents at the meso-positions.

The replacement of meso-phenyl substituents by thienyl substituents, for example in SubPs 401 (Table 25), shifts both Q- and B-bands to red (400 and 534 nm, respectively), indicating again large electronic influences of the meso-thienyl substituents on the SubP core. The fluorescence is observed at 632 nm with a high fluorescence quantum yield of 0.45.586

The -conjugation of SubPs can be further extended by elongation of three meso-aryl chains by substitution with 1,4-oligophenylene branches (compounds 503 and 504).623 Besides, conjugated systems can be anchored to the SubP meso-positions by using vinylene and ethyne linkers, shifting both B- and Q-bands to lower energies. Because of their lesser steric demand, a sole alkene (compound 512) or alkyne (SubPs 513520) unit produces considerably stronger effects than the three phenylene units in compounds 503 and 504.

In general, the fluorescence quantum yields also increase in the order 390 510 < 503 512 513 < 504 < 516 517, probably as a reflection of the increasing size of the effective radiative chromophore. Comparative effects between non-conjugated (SubPs 510 and 511) and conjugated (SubPs 512520) meso-substituents are illustrated in Table 25. Other conjugated substituents such as aldehyde and carboxylic acid produce comparable effects in the absorption spectra of SubPs 306 and 307, respectively.631

Diverse heteroatoms directly attached to the meso-positions also cause significant alterations in the absorption and emission spectra of SubP chromophores. In particular, nitro (SubP 555) and amino substituents (SubPs 556, 523526) cause red shifts in B and Q-absorption bands and fluorescence bands in different extents (Table 25). The nitro substituent leads to quenching the fluorescence quantum yields, as observed for other derivatives. The effects of bromo (508), ether (527, 503), thioether (531, 534) and phosphoryl (535) substituents are much weaker (Table 25), and the absorption spectra of these compounds are comparable to that of 390.627 When a sulfanyl (531 and 534) or phosphoryl (535) group is directly attached at the meso-position, red-shifted absorption and fluorescence spectra are observed with concurrent substantial decreases in the fluorescence quantum yields due to the heavy atom effect.

Ethylation at the six -pyrrole positions results in blue shifted Soret bands with respect to their related -free compounds as seen for SubPs 411 and 412 whose Soret bands are observed at 360 and 339 nm, respectively. Curiously, the Q-bands appear blue-shifted to 448 and 471 nm for 411 and red-shifted to 437 and 463 nm for the meso-unsubstituted 412 (Fig. 111). The blue shift in the Soret bands of 411 and 412 has been attributed to the electron-rich ethyl substituents.594 In line with this, the electron-poor -trifluoromethyl-substituted SubP 464 displays absorption bands at 396, 488, and 518 nm,610 which are considerably red shifted with respect to the unsubstituted SubP 570 (Scheme 50) (369, 456, 480 nm).637 It is probable that the steric congestion between the meso-phenyl rings and -alkyl substituents reduces effective conjugation of the meso-phenyl substituent, hence causing the observed blue shift of the absorption bands of 411. Contrary to this consideration, the more congested SubPs 456 and 457 containing meso-aryl and -phenyl substituents display red-shifted B-bands (382 nm) with respect to the -unsubstituted 401 (373 nm) (Fig. 112).


Fig. 111 Absorption (red line) and emission (blue line) spectra in CH2Cl2 and simulated absorption bands (black) of (a) 411 and (b) and 412. Reproduced with permission from ref. 594.

Fig. 112 Absorption (solid lines) and fluorescence broken lines) spectra of BzSubPs; (a) 387 and (b) 388 in CH2Cl2, and calculated absorption bands. Adapted with permission from ref. 7 and 581. Copyright 2006 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

Steady-state fluorescence spectra of 411 and 412 display clear vibronic structures with peaks at 477 and 507 nm, and 469, 481 and 496 nm, respectively (Fig. 111). The fluorescence spectra are the mirror images of their corresponding Q-bands in the absorption spectra. Small Stokes shifts indicate the structural rigidity of the excited states of these SubPs. The fluorescence quantum yields of 411 and 412 were determined to be 0.20 and 0.12, respectively, which are considerably higher than those of the corresponding meso-alkylated SubPs (ca. 0.07).

Naturally, tris--benzene-fused SubPs 387 and 388 show red-shifted absorption and fluorescence spectra. Observed roughly similar spectra of these two SubPs suggested that the influence of the meso-phenyl substituents in 388 was only marginal, probably because of the restricted rotation of the meso-phenyl groups due to the steric congestion between the fused rings and meso-phenyl groups (Fig. 112).

The absorption spectrum of -hexaethynyl substituted SubP 458 shows considerably red-shifted Soret bands (51 nm red shift with respect to 390). The effect is even stronger for -hexaphenylethynylated SubP 454 (70 nm red shift). These examples indicate effective -conjugation of the -ethynyl substituents with the macrocyclic core.609 The corresponding fluorescence spectra show vibronic structure with similar fluorescence quantum yields to 390.

-Substitution with heteroatoms such as Br and Cl in SubPs h, iodine in compound 477, and sulfur in 460463, leads to effective fluorescence quenching as a consequence of the heavy-atom effect.609,611,617 Besides, the absorption spectra of hexaarylsulfanyl SubPs 460 and 461 are significantly perturbed, featuring red-shifted and split Soret-like bands at 376, 415 nm and 388, 423 nm, respectively, in addition to red-shifted Q-like bands at 507, 536 nm and 501, 528 nm, respectively. The absorption spectra of 462 and 463 show non-split red-shifted Soret-like bands and red-shifted Q-like bands.611

SubP 475 (Scheme 43) bearing one nitro group at one of the -positions shows a split Soret-like band at 341 and 395 nm and a red-shifted, broad Q-type band at 513 nm. The emission band is solvent-polarity dependent, appearing in CH2Cl2 significantly red-shifted at 656 nm, with low quantum yield of 0.08.612 -Aminosubporphyrin 476 also displays a broad Soret-like band at 366 nm and a slightly red-shifted, Q-type band at 474 nm, following similar tendencies as meso-substitution. -Arylamino-SubPs 469472 show red shifted absorptions as well, although the spectra are considerably different from those of meso-arylamino-SubPs.612 The fluorescence quantum yields of 469 and 470 in CH2Cl2 are lower (F = 0.12 and 0.05, respectively) than that of SubP 523, while the corresponding Stokes shifts are 2410 and 3200 cm1, respectively, being much larger than that of 523 (1380 cm1), suggesting charge-transfer character for emitting species. meso-Substituted SubPs 471 and 472 are almost non-fluorescent in CH2Cl2, thereby plausibly indicating reductive and oxidative intramolecular electron-transfer quenching in their S1 states.

For SubPcs and SubPzs, the axial fluorine substituents do not alter the optical spectra significantly.159 Similarly, SubP 570 displays very similar UV-vis, MCD and fluorescence spectra to the hydroxo- and methoxo-derivatives.637 The Soret-like and Q-like bands of hydride SubP 597 are observed at 387 and 512 nm, with the fluorescence profile peaking at 560 nm with an absolute fluorescence quantum yield of 0.13.641 The absorption and fluorescence spectra of peroxo-substituted SubPs 602604 are also quite similar to those of 390.642

The effects of the axial carbon ligands on the absorption spectra of SubPs are very weak. Thus, compounds with BC bonds 574583 show Soret-like bands in the 382385 nm range and Q-like bands in the 501508 nm range. B-bands of 584 and 585, on the other hand, appear comparatively blue and red shifted, respectively, at 379 and 389 nm.638

Fig. 113 shows the absorption and fluorescence spectra of 390, 570, 574, 597, 585 and 584.


Fig. 113 UV-vis absorption (solid lines) and fluorescence (dashed lines) spectra of SuPs 390, 570, 574, 597, 584 and 585 in CH2Cl2. Fluorescence spectra were recorded upon excitation at the peak maxima of each Soret-like bands. Adapted with permission from ref. 641. Copyright 2015 American Chemical Society.

Both the Soret- and Q-like bands are red-shifted in the order 570 < 390 < 584 < 574 < 597 < 585, reflecting the increasing electron-donating abilities of the axial substituents. The emission bands red-shifted exactly in the same order in good agreement with the respective Hammett inductive constants of the axial substituents. The corresponding fluorescence quantum yields are variable. Many of BC SubPs exhibit fluorescence quantum yields (F = 0.100.16) similar to that of 390, while strong fluorescence quenching is observed for donors in SubPs 577 and 579 that bear a strong donating axial group and in SubP 585 that bears an alkyl group.638

6.3.4 Photoexcited state dynamics. The photoexcited state dynamics of nitrophenyl-SubPs 440443, with different rotational freedom because of the lack of methyl group (440), or different positions for the methyl group, namely, 3- (441), 3,5- (442) and 2-position (443), were compared to those of SubP 390. 443 has a severe rotational barrier of the nitrophenyl group, while the barrier for 441 and 442 are different.605 Transient absorption measurements showed different times for CS and CR in these SubPs, indicating that weak charge recombination-associated emission is only allowed for SubPs with freely rotating aryl groups. In particular, 390 displayed very rapid formation and decay of the CS state, showing broad absorbance in the range of 500630 nm consisting of contributions from the [SubP+] and the nitrobenzene anion radical, with a CS rate of (3.7 ps)1 and a CR rate of (330 ps)1. The corresponding spectra of 441 and 442 also displayed quantitative CS and CR, with kCS = (3.0 ps)1 and kCR = (530 ps)1 for 441, and kCS = (2 ps)1 and kCR = (210 ps)1 for 442. The fluorescence lifetimes of 390, 441 and 442 (340, 510, and 200 ps, respectively) matched with the lifetimes for CR processes, indicating that their red-shifted fluorescence in CH2Cl2 is originating from the CS state. The TA spectra of 443, with an orthogonal conformation, indicated the rise and decay of a broad absorbance in the 480660 nm range, arising from the CS state, with kCS = (5.0 ps)1 and kCR = (40 ps)1. The lack of red-shifted fluorescence can be explained by the very fast CR, producing a short-lived CS state.

Photoinduced electron transfer processes have also been studied on meso-arylethynyl SubPs 513, 515, 516 and 516H+.574

After photoexcitation into the FranckCondon state, amino-subporphyrin 516 followed an adiabatic pathway to the CS state, with a time constant of 0.4 ps, whereas the CS state underwent CR, with a time constant of ca. 700 ps. In contrast, the TA of the nitro-SubP 515 in acetonitrile showed that the CS took place with a time constant of 2.8 ps, while CR occurred with a time constant of 20 ps. The latter is consistent with the negligible CS state emission in 515. The energy levels of the charge separated states for 513, 515 and 516 were estimated to be 2.35, 1.95 and 2.08 eV. Protonated SubP 516, on the other hand, recovered an increased fluorescence quantum yield, indicating the absence of CS state upon irradiation.

The excited state dynamics of meso-arylamino-SubPs 523, 524 and 525 were also studied, revealing these SubPs as good platforms of twisted intramolecular charge transfer (TICT). Thus, photoexcitation of 523 leads to the population of the locally excited state (LE) that has a slow transient absorption decay and high fluorescence quantum yield. In contrast, photoexcitation of 524 produces rise and decay profiles with time constants of 3.5 and 44 ps, respectively. The time constant of 3.5 ps indicates that the formation time of the CS state involves the structural twisting motion at the CmesoN bond, to trigger the intramolecular charge transfer, giving subporphyrin anion radical and 1,4-diaminobenzene cation radical.

Similarly, photoexcitation of 525 produces decay and rise times of excited state absorption signals of 9 ps. The population of LE is transferred to the CS state, undergoing twisting of the NCipso bond to trigger the opposite charge separated state, to give a subporphyrin cation radical and a nitrobenzene anion radical.645

The effect of bulky groups in the TICT processes have been studied using diarylamino-SubPs 536, 538 and 539.646 Due to rotation restriction, the electronic structures of these SubPs are more perturbed than those of 523525. As a result, the TICT process is less efficient in 539 than in 525. As a proof of the TICT mechanism, the fused diarylamino SubP 562 (R = NMe2), with completely restricted rotation of the diarylamino moiety, exhibits fluorescence, contrasting with the fluorescence quenching observed for 524 and 538 due to TICT.623

6.3.5 Redox properties. Owing to their superb spin-delocalization abilities over almost the entire molecule, SubPs are able to stabilize radical species. Thus, oxidation of meso-hydroxy-,647 amino630 or dicyanomethyl-SubPs629 with PbO2 provides the corresponding meso-oxy (607), meso-aminyl (608) and meso-dicyanomethyl (609) radicals (Fig. 114).
Fig. 114 Subporphyrin-based stable radicals.

With respect to their electrochemical features, meso-unsubstituted BzSubP 387 is by 0.75 V easier to oxidize than the corresponding SubPc.189 On the other hand, -hexaethyl SubP 412 is 0.21 V easier to oxidize that the parallel -hexapropyl SubPz 276.63 Both comparisons illustrate the more electron-deficient nature of the meso-triaza-Subporphyrinoids with respect to meso-carbon macrocycles. Electrochemical studies the other meso-unsubstituted SubPs 415, 430 and 358 have not been reported.

Comparing BzSubPs and SubPs, meso-triphenylSubP 390 is by 0.51 V more difficult to oxidize and 0.40 V easier to reduce than the corresponding benzoannulated compound 388. For meso-arylated SubPs such as 390, 395398, 407 and 409, the first one-electron oxidations are reversible waves in the range of 0.641.02 V versus the ferrocene/ferrocenium ion couple, while the second oxidation steps are irreversible. A plot of the first oxidation potentials of these SubPs versus the Hammett values constitutes a straight line. Compounds 390, 395398, 407 and 409 show their first reduction potential in the 1.30 to 1.83 range. Besides, except for the nitro-derivative 397, a plot of the first reduction potentials versus the Hammett values also constitutes a straight line, suggesting that the first reductions of these SubPs take place at the SubP -system (LUMO orbital).2

Both oxidation and reduction couples shift depending on the donating or withdrawing nature of the substituents, as well as the position, i.e. meso-, - and axial, at which they are attached. Alkylation at the meso-positions has a little impact (0.01 V cathodic shift) on the oxidation potential of SubP 491 (Table 26), while the reduction wave is cathodically shifted by 0.34 V with respect to the triphenylated 390, denoting the electron richer character of meso-alkyl SubPs, related to the meso-phenyl compounds.586 Alkylation at the -positions produces a stronger effect. In fact, neither 411 or 412 show any reduction process up to 2.0 V.594 In addition, 411 shows a quasi-reversible first oxidation potential at 0.59 V and a second irreversible one at 1.24 V, whereas 412 shows the first reversible oxidation potential at 0.62 V and the second irreversible at 1.19 V. Anyway, the strongest effect is observed upon alkylation at the axial position in 585, which shows its first oxidation and reduction processes at 0.52 and 2.14 V, respectively.
