524 Ph Ph 4-Me2NC6H4NH H OMe 2.14 0.18 2.32 625
525 Ph Ph 4-NO2C6H4NH H OMe 1.87 0.42 2.29 625
526 Ph Ph H OMe 2.09 0.11 2.20 627

As a general trend, axial coordination with carbon-based electron-donating groups produces the highest effects in the redox properties of SubPs, related to the meso- (compare, for example, 576 with 392 and 579 with 405 in Table 26) or -substitution (compare, for example, 457 with 574 and 455 with 338 in Table 26). In this respect, SubPs 574585 show more negative oxidation (0.17 to 0.68 V) and reduction potentials (1.93 to 2.14 V) than 390, with both processes shifted by the same extent. The latter results in similar electrochemical HOMOLUMO gaps for 574585, lying in the of 2.572.66 eV range. Exceptions are aminophenyl- (577) and ferrocene (579) substituted SubPs, with electrochemical HOMOLUMO gaps of 2.36 and 1.84 eV, respectively. For the latter compounds the first oxidation processes appear at 0.32 and 0.17 V, corresponding to the oxidation of the 4-dimethylaminophenyl and ferrocene moieties, respectively. The equivalent oxidation of meso-triferrocene-SubP 405 has been observed as a split wave at 0.028 and 0.14 V, a fact that has been interpreted as a diagnostic of effective electronic communication among the appended ferrocene units.592 The HOMOLUMO gap of 405 is also considerably reduced to 2.05 eV, and the same occurs for other SubPs substituted with electron-donating groups as seen in thiophene-substituted SubP 401 (2.16 eV).586

The redox couples of compounds endowed with electron withdrawing groups such as 394397 (Table 26) appear at more positive potentials. SubPs 396 and 397, containing conjugated electron-withdrawing substituents at the para-positions, exhibit different multireduction processes. In particular, 4-cyanophenyl-substituted SubP 396 displays three single-electron reduction waves at 1.53, 1.73, and 1.90 V, whereas and 4-nitrophenyl-substituted SubP 397 shows a three-electron reduction wave at 1.30 V. For 397, the deviation from linearity of the plot of the first reduction potential versus the nitro Hammett parameter suggests that the first reduction process might occur at the 4-nitrophenyl groups.2

Comparison of the effects of electron-withdrawing groups at the meso-, - and axial positions suggests a different trend with respect to the above discussed effect of electron-donating groups. Thus, compared to 390, meso-4-cyanophenyl- (396) and meso-4-bromophenyl- (393) substituents shift the first oxidation potentials anodically by 0.24 and 0.06 V, respectively, while reduction processes are also anodically shifted by 0.29 and 0.12 V, correspondingly.2 However, the same substitution patterns produce weaker effects when they are at the axial site. Thus, for example, the oxidation potentials of the axial cyanophenyl-SubP 588 and bromophenyl-SubP 590 appear 0.14 and 0.08 V anodically shifted, respectively, compared to the axial phenyl-SubP 574, whereas the reduction processes are 0.07 V more difficult for 588 and 0.05 V easier for 590.639 Other electron-withdrawing substituents such as aldehyde, carboxylic acid (SubP 548 and SubP 549 in Table 22)631 and ester (Table 26)603 or trifluoromethyl (Table 26) shift the redox potentials towards more positive values. For example, 4-trifluoromethyl-moieties anodically shift both oxidation and reduction processes around 0.35 V when they are attached at the meso-phenyl rings (compare compounds 570 and 572 in Table 26) and around 1.00 V when they are directly attached to the -positions (compare SubPs 572 and 466 in Table 26). Likewise, the two-meso-esters of 437 anodically shift to 1.00 V the first oxidation potential and to 1.6 V the first reduction wave.603

SubPs 389 and 390, bearing axial hydroxo- and methoxo-substituents, respectively show similar values for the first oxidation and reduction potentials.3 The replacement of the oxo-substituent by fluorine in 570 leads both the oxidation (+0.13 V) and reduction waves (+0.04 V) to more positive potentials.641 Axial hydride (SubP 597) dramatically shifts the oxidation peak to 0.36 V, while axial peroxides produce weaker influence. In particular, the first one-electron reductions of 602, 603 and 604 are quasi-irreversible, suggesting that the one-electron reduction induces OO bond cleavage. Besides, the first reduction potentials are positively shifted in the order 603 (1.94 V) < 602 (1.81 V) < 604 (1.70 V), reflecting the electron-donating abilities of the peroxy substituents.642

The effect of heteroatoms at the pyrrole -positions of SubPs varies according to the electronic nature of the substituents. HexabromoSubPs (h) present anodic potential shift of both oxidation and reduction waves (Table 26) indicating that inductive effects of bromine are dominant for modulating the electrochemical potentials.609 -Sulfanyl-SubPs 460462 (Table 26) show one irreversible oxidation process at 0.65, 0.77, and 0.67 V, respectively, roughly similar to 390. More different, the corresponding oxidation wave of SubP 463 appears at 0.55 V.611 The cathodic window, however, shows one reversible reduction wave for each compound at 1.63, 1.58, 1.79, and 1.79 V, respectively, significantly more positive than that of 390. Monofunctionalized -sulfanylSubP 467 (Fig. 101) shows redox features more similar to those of 390, namely at 0.79 and 1.95 V, corresponding to the oxidation and reduction waves, respectively.611

A single nitro- or amino-substituent attached at the -position produces much stronger impact in SubPs 475 and 476 (Scheme 43), respectively or in arylamino-SubPs 469472 (Fig. 101).612 For example, the first one-electron oxidation and reduction potentials of SubPs 475 and 476 appear at 0.82 and 1.39 V and 0.28 and 2.08 V, that is, more positive (E = +19 and +60 V) and more negative (E = 35 and 0.09 V), respectively, than those of the corresponding SubP 409 (Table 26 and Fig. 115).612 The electrochemical HOMOLUMO gaps for 475 (2.21 eV), arylamines 469472 (2.102.46 eV) and 476 (2.36 eV) are calculated to be smaller than that of compound 409 (2.62 eV).


Fig. 115 Cyclic voltammograms (black) and a differential pulse voltammogram (grey) of SubPs 409, 475 and 476. Supporting electrolyte: 0.10 M tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate in CH2Cl2. Adapted with permission from ref. 612. Copyright 2013 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

The corresponding potentials of the meso-substituted nitro-SubP 555 and amino-SubP 557 (Scheme 48) are much more influenced. For 555, the redox features appear still more positively shifted appearing at 1.23 (oxidation, E = +0.52 V) and 1.20 V (reduction, E = +0.77 V), while for 557, they are negatively shifted to 0.11 V (oxidation, E = 0.60) and 2.19 V (reduction, E = 0.22 V).632 The effect of the amino group is comparable to that produced by another aliphatic amines such as 526 (Table 26). Together with axially substituted hydride- (597) and aminophenyl-SubPs (577), as well as meso-tris-ferrocene-SubP (405) and tris-thienyl-SubP 401, SubPs bearing amino groups directly attached to the meso positions (523526) are among the easiest to electrochemically oxidize, with oxidation potentials ranging from 0.18 V for the p-dimethylaminoanilino-substituted compound 524 to 0.42 V for the p-nitroanilino-derivative 525.

The electrochemical potentials of SubP radical species 607609 appear in the 0.200.47 V range for oxidation waves and 0.29 to 0.40 V range for reduction processes. On the basis of these values, the corresponding excitation energy gaps to the S1 state has been estimated to be in the 0.750.85 eV range.629,630,647

6.3.6 Theoretical calculations. DFT studies on the electronic structures and IR spectra of SubPs were reported with the exchangecorrelation (XC) functional of Perdew, Burke and Ernzerhof (PBEPBE) coupled to the DGDZVP basis set.648 Besides, the electronic structure, absorption spectra, and 1H and 13C-NMR spectra of the hydroxyboron(III) SubP complex, as well as the free-base SubP, had been performed at the B3LYP/6-311G(2d,p)//B3LYP/6-31G(d) theory level.521 Both reports have been previously reviewed by some of us.1

Trends in the electronic structures and optical properties of ring contracted porphyrins have been analyzed by comparing the properties of SubPs with those of triphyrins and vacataporphyrins, using cyclic polyene perimeter-model approaches, such as Gouterman's four-orbital model and Michl's perimeter model.649

More recently, exploration of the ground and excited states to determine absorption and emission properties of SubPs and BzSubPs, including the 00 energies and the vibronic couplings, has been carried out using PCM-TD-DFT calculations. Comparison of the aromaticity of SubPs with that of other porphyrinoids, as well as the impact of meso-substitution on the SubP core, has been rationalized.215 The NICS values computed at the centers of the rings have been estimated to be of 20.6 for SubP and 19.1 for BzSubP, in line with those calculated for the corresponding triaza-analogues (20.7 for SubPzs and 18.7 for SubPcs). With respect to the optical properties, the Q-bands have been predicted to involve changes in the electronic density upon photon absorption, to be mainly localized in the center of the macrocycles, with the pyrrolic nitrogens and the meso-atoms gaining electronic density, while the -carbon atoms lose it (Fig. 116). The Soret band involves more delocalized excited states. For the benzo-analogues BzSubP and SubPc, the analysis of the vibrational modes signals two families of modes playing a key role: the first one at 500750 cm1, accounting for shoulder at ca. 15 nm from the 00 band, and the second one at 14001500 cm1 being responsible for the presence of a secondary maximum in BzSubP, or the enlargement of the band in SubPc (Fig. 116).


Fig. 116 Density difference plots (isovalue = 0.0008 a.u.) corresponding to the absorption of light of the first excited states involved in the Q (top) and Soret (bottom) bands of subporphyrinoid systems. Red (blue) regions indicate a gain (loss) of electronic density upon photon absorption. Reproduced with permission from ref. 215. Copyright 2017 American Chemical Society.

6.4 Synthesis and properties of subporphyrin oligomers and complex systems

6.4.1 Subporphyrin oligomers connected at the meso positions. SubP dimers connected with biphenylene,583 bithiophene621 and butadiyne585 bridges, as well as complex dendritic carbazole-functionalized,590,591 or capped588 SubPs, had been previously reported and reviewed by some of us.1

More recently, a meso-to-meso directly linked SubP dimer 610 (Fig. 117) has been assembled in 72% yield by reductive coupling of bromo-SubP 508 in the presence of [Ni(cod)2] and 1,5-cyclooctadiene.604 Bis-SubP 610 shows slow rotation through the mesomeso bridge, with H, S and G298 values of the rotation barrier of 14.7 kcal mol1, 1.28 cal mol1 K1, and 14.3 kcal mol1, respectively. The SubP units show a mean bowl depth of 1.33 , and BB distance of 7.21 , with a dihedral angle of 55.58 between the two subporphyrin cores. In accordance, the absorption spectrum of 610 shows a Soret-like band at 403 nm with a broad shoulder around 388 nm, and broadened Q-like bands with two peaks at 462 and 516 nm and a tail extending over 550 nm. Besides, 610 shows emission at 593 nm with a large Stokes shift (2520 cm1). These optical features suggest conjugative interactions of the two SubP units due to the small rotational barrier of the mesomeso bond, in addition to excitonic interaction between the chromophores.


Fig. 117 Structures of mesomeso-linked SubPs.

SubP dimers connected with trans-ethylene (611) and acetylene (612) linkers (Fig. 117) have been prepared by Stille and Sonogashira coupling reactions, respectively, using bromo-SubP like 508 as the precursor. Specifically, treatment of 508 with trans-1,2-bis(tributylstannyl)ethene afforded 611 in 36% yield. Dimer 612 was prepared in 61% overall yield by using a three-step procedure consisting of Sonogashira reaction of 508 with ethynyltrimethylsilane, followed by deprotection and Sonogashira coupling of the triple bond with 508.650 The crystal structures of 611 and 612 show anti arrangements of the macrocycles favorable for electronic communication, with a slightly tilted (26.6) ethylene linker, whereas the acetylene bridge is almost coplanar to the SubP rings. Indeed, both dimers show significantly red shifted and intensified Q-bands at 660 and 630 nm, respectively, with a tail reaching around 700750 nm. The fluorescence bands are also bathochromically shifted and enhanced, indicating large structural changes in the S1-state, as a result of the effective conjugation between the two chromophores.

meso-Lithium SubP, obtained by bromine-lithium exchange of bromo-SubP derivatives such as 508, has been employed to synthesize SubP dimers 613, 614, and 615 (Fig. 117), by reaction with 1,2-dichlorotetramethylsilane, dimethyl carbonate, and formyl-SubP 548, respectively.631 The dihedral angles between the carbonyl group and the two SubP rings are small (33.7 and 23.6, respectively) for the ketone 614, suitable for extended conjugation over the entire molecule. In fact, the corresponding absorption spectrum was found to be largely redshifted, owing to the effective electronic communication of the two SubP units through the carbonyl linker. On the other hand, the SiSi bond takes a nearly perpendicular orientation in dimer 613 (87.9 with respect to the SubP core), favorable for conjugation, which contributes to slightly red-shifted Q-bands.

Other meso-to-meso linked SubP dimers have been connected through azo- (616), amino- (617), sulfide- (618) and disulfide- (619) bridges (Fig. 117). Oxidation of amino-SubP 557 with PbO2 afforded the meso-to-meso azo-SubP dimer 616 in 83% yield, presumably intermediated by the corresponding aminyl radical of 608 type.632 Dimer 616 shows fairly coplanar stacking arrangement favorable for electronic conjugative interaction. This results in largely perturbed and red-shifted absorption spectra, with split Soret (339, 423 nm) and Q-bands (654, 704 nm), accompanied by quenched fluorescence.

Bis-SubP amine 617 has been obtained in 46% yield by SNAr reaction of chloro-SubP 509 with amino-SubP 557.630 Due to its electron rich nature, dimer 617 is unstable under aerobic conditions, and tends to generate the corresponding aminyl radical as a fairly stable species.

S-bridged dimer 618 has been assembled in 43% yield by treating chloro-SubP 509 with 0.55 equiv. of Na2S9H2O in the presence of catalytic amount of n-Bu4NBr. When 1.5 equiv. of Na2S9H2O were employed for this reaction, the SS-linked dimer 619 was obtained in 35% yield, presumably arising from aerobic oxidation of the corresponding monomeric SubP-thiol during the workup.651 The average bowl depth for SubP units in dimer 618 is of 1.38 , with a dihedral angle between the two macrocycles of 86.7. This orthogonal arrangement precludes electronic interaction between the two chromophores, giving rise to red shifted fluorescence, as well as split Soret band, together with broad Q-bands; the optical features have been rationalized in terms of exciton coupling between the two SubP entities. A large Stokes shift of 2670 cm1 is indicative of substantial structural changes in the excited state. The SubP components of disulfide 619 experience less electronic perturbation than the sulfide counterpart and quenched fluorescence, owing to the very short lifetime of its S1 excited state.

6.4.2 Subporphyrin dimers connected at the -positions. syn- and anti--to- 1,3-butadiyne-bridged SubP dimers 620 (Scheme 54) were prepared in around 30% yields by deprotection reaction of 2,13-bis-(tert-butyldimethylsilylethynyl)-SubP 485, followed by oxidative dimerization by treatment with Cu(OAc)2.617 Both syn- and anti-isomers show in their crystal structures non-equivalent CC units and distortions of the triple bonds, with no substantial differences in their butadiyne CC bond lengths. The average SubP bowl depths are of 1.46 for the syn- and of 1.50 for the anti-isomers, with BB distances of 11.92 and 11.97 , respectively. Both syn- and anti-dimers exhibit split Soret bands at 409 and 453 nm and 406 and 441 nm, respectively, accompanied by bathochromically shifted Q-bands at 557, 583, and 554 nm, correspondingly, as diagnostic of large electronic coupling between the two macrocycles. The differences in the absorption profiles of the two isomers have been explained in terms of exciton coupling using dipoledipole approximation developed by Kasha.652
Scheme 54 Synthesis of -to- 1,3-butadiyne-bridged SubP dimers 620.

Directly -to--connected dimer 623 was synthesized by reductive coupling of -iodo SubP 622, which was in turn prepared by controlled borylation of SubP 621 and subsequent iodination (Scheme 55).619 In order to accomplish the peripheral borylation, the axial group must be changed to a nonpolar tolyl. Dimer 623 was obtained as an inseparable 1:1 mixture of DL and meso-diastereomers, from which preferential crystallization of the DL-diastereomer was achieved. In the solid state, DL to meso isomerization was not observed. However, pure DL-diastereomer was isomerized in methanol at 50 C, giving a diastereomeric 2:1 mixture of DL- and meso-623, thus suggesting the occurrence of SubP bowl inversion. Because of the lesser steric congestion around the -positions, the average CC bond length in DL-623 is of 1.44 , and the dihedral angle between the two macrocycles is of 29.3, much smaller than that observed for the meso-to-meso dimer 610. DL-623 shows a red-shifted Soret band that is rationalized in terms of exciton coupling between the two SubPs, in addition to sharp Q-bands at 464 and 509 nm. Observed smaller Stokes shift (1160 cm1) related to that of other SubP dimers indicates less structural relaxation of DL-623 in the excited state.


Scheme 55 Synthesis of the -to--dimers 623.
6.4.3 Subporphyrin systems connected through the axial positions. Some SubP arrays connected at the axial position20,36 and -oxodimers637 have been reviewed by some of us.1 As explained above, the peroxo-bridged subporphyrin dimer 605 has been prepared by heating hydroxo-peroxide 602.641

meso-Axially attached SubP trimer 625 has been obtained serendipitously by SNAr reaction of chloro-SubP 509 with potassium hydroxide.647 The formation of the triangular trimer has been rationalized by considering a spontaneous self-assembly of the SubP alcohol 624 (Scheme 56).


Scheme 56 Synthesis of meso-to-axial cyclic SubP trimer 625.

In 625, the SubP bowl depths are of 1.267, 1.354 and 1.356 . Its UV-vis spectrum displays a split Soret band, suggestive of strong through-space exciton coupling between the neighboring SubP units, enabled by the short interchromophoric separation distance of 7 . The trimer was monomerized to the corresponding meso-hydroxy-SubP 624 upon treatment with methanol.

More recently, a related meso-axially attached SubP dimer 626 has been assembled by Shimizu and co-workers in 9% yield, through an ether cleavage reaction of the A2B-type subporphyrin bearing an ortho-anisyl substituent 431 (Scheme 57). Despite the spatial proximity between the two subporphyrin chromophores in 626, the dimer exhibited similar UV-vis absorption, MCD and fluorescence spectra than the corresponding monomer, indicating minor interchromophore interactions in 626.653


Scheme 57 Synthesis of meso-to-axial cyclic SubP dimer 626.
6.4.4 Fused subporphyrin dimers. meso-to-meso and -to--doubly linked SubP dimer 627 (Fig. 118) was prepared as a single anti-isomer by selective dibromination of DL-623 at the two free-meso-positions followed by coupling in the presence of [Ni(cod)2].619 The average bowl-depth for the SubPs is of 1.42 in 627, and the dihedral angles between the two macrocycles are of 22.9 at the meso-position and 17.3 at the -position, that is, smaller than that of DL-623 and favorable for extended -conjugation. In fact, the elongation of the conjugation produces an absorption spectrum for 627 displaying broad and red-shifted B and Q-bands at 444 and 641 nm, respectively, the latter with a tail reaching around 850 nm (Fig. 119), and almost completely quenched fluorescence.654
Fig. 118 Structures of 627631.

Fig. 119 UV-vis-NIR absorption spectra of 438 and 627630 in CH2Cl2. Adapted with permission from ref. 655. Copyright 2017 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

Doubly Pt-bridged SubP dimer 628 was synthesized in 64% yield as a sole syn-isomer by treating ,-diboryl-SubP j (Scheme 44) with Pt(cod)Cl2 in the presence of CsF and COD. 628 was oxidized with magic blue to give 629, which was subsequently refluxed in toluene, in the presence of 1,3-bis(diphenylphosphino)propane, affording triply linked SubP dimer 630 as a result of reductive elimination.655 The crystal structure of dimer 628 revealed a square planar Pt ion coordinated in a cis-manner and holding a face-to-face SubP arrangement. The triply fused dimer 630 takes a domed structure with a positive Gaussian curvature. The calculated bowl-depth of the SubP halves is of 1.65 , much larger than that of SubP monomers, and indicating that the triple linkage forces additional structural strain. 630 displays absorption bands at 315, 403, 500, 810, and 942 nm (Fig. 119). A narrow optical HOMOLUMO gap clearly suggests the effective conjugation extending over the whole molecule. The absorption bands at 315, 403, and 500 nm have been assigned as split Soret-like bands. The absorption spectrum of 629 is clearly different from that of 627, but similar to that of 630, suggesting substantial interaction through the Pt-linkage.

syn- and anti-,-Dithiino-SubP dimers 631 were prepared through a seven-step synthetic procedure and separated by chromatography at the end. The sequence started from arylsulfanyl-Sub 467 (Fig. 101), and had a key step consisting in the SNAr reaction between a SubP ,-thiol and a SubP -Br,-sulfone.656 Dimers 631 are conformationally very flexible, as indicated by analysis of different crystals. Hence, while the crystals of the anti-isomer showed a completely planar configuration, distinct crystals of the syn-isomer showed various conformations, going from a bent-towards-the-convex-sides structure to an almost planar conformation. The UV-vis spectra exhibit similar features for both isomers, characterized by split Soret bands arising from exciton coupling between the two SubP macrocycles, accompanying a Q-band around 490 nm. Both syn- and anti-631 formed 1:1 cocrystallates upon treatment with C60 and C70. In addition, the syn-isomer was able to capture both fullerenes in toluene, with high association constants that exceed 106 M1.

6.4.5 Subporphyrin-based hybrid systems. The preparation of some SubP hybrids containing bodipy,623 1,4-quinone,589 ferrocene592 and porphyrin657 have been previously reviewed by some of us.1 For the latter, fast excitation energy transfer processes from the SubP to the porphyrin units have been reported to occur. These photoinduced events are enabled by the -conjugative elongation of the SubP onto the phenylene linkers, as if SubP and ZnP were directly attached.658

meso- and axially appended SubP-based electron donoracceptor (DA) conjugates, have been assembled using 1,1,4,4-tetracyanobuta-1,3-diene (TCBD)aniline (SubPs 632 and 633) and naphthalenediimide (SubPs 634) as the strong electron-acceptor counterparts. SubPs 632 and 633 were prepared by CARE reactions of meso-alkynyl-SubP 516 and axial alkynyl 584-like SubP, respectively, with TCNE.45 The crystal structures show highly nonplanar conformations for the TCBC units, leading to two enantiomers that are obtained as racemates in 632 and 633. The two R and S enantiomers of 633 were separated by chiral HPLC, while the corresponding meso-isomers 632 displayed structural flexibility that precluded the corresponding enantiomeric separation. The electronic interaction between the SubP and the TCBDaniline unit is also influenced by the position to which the acceptor unit is attached. In particular, the attachment at the axial position in 633 produces less perturbation, since a large HOMOLUMO gap of 2.12 eV disables any emissive CT state, and enforces an emissive exciplex deactivation in apolar environments next to the SubP-centered fluorescence; in polar environments, a CS state is generated.

Contrasting, the meso-substituted SubP 632 showed strong electronic coupling between the donor and acceptor units, owing to the very reduced HOMOLUMO gap of 1.77 eV, enabling an emissive CT state in virtually all environments, although it is only in polar environments, where it links a local excitation with an indirect CS.

Five dyads, namely, 634, 6342Me, 6343Me, 6342,6Me, 6343,6Me (see Fig. 120) were synthesized by SuzukiMiyaura coupling with bromo-SubP 508 with the corresponding NDI-Bpin derivatives.659 The absorption and emission spectra of all the dyads were very similar to the sum of their components, with the SubP chromophore dominating the spectra because of its much larger molar absorptivity with respect to the NDI unit. Measurements on the fluorescence decays for the five dyads show that there is a systematic variation of the singlet excited state lifetime with the substitution pattern ranging from 515 ps, which corresponds to near quantitative CS. TA measurements revealed that both CS and CR times vary systematically with steric bulk, reflecting that the electronic coupling between the SubP and the NDI becomes smaller as the dihedral angles between the two subunits are increased.


Fig. 120 Structures of hybrids 632634. The number 2 in 6342Me indicates the position of the methyl substituent(s) on the phenyl spacer. 634 alone indicates no methyl group.

6.5 Applications of subporphyrin and subporphyrin hybrids

Compared to SubPcs, studies on the applications of SubPs to different technological fields still remain in their infancy. Axial functionalization of BzSubP 387 with a 5-mercaptopentyloxy unit to give 635 (Fig. 121) allowed to anchor the dye to the Au(111) surface via reaction with 1-heptanethiol linkers that were preorganized as a self-assembled monolayer (C7S SAM) on the Au(111) substrate, so that the SubP was electronically decoupled from the metal surface. STM differential conductance (dI/dV V) measurements with the bare W tip exhibited a broad gap region of low conductance and three distinct responses at 2.4, 1.3, and 2.1 V.636
Fig. 121 Structures of BzSubP 635 and SubPs 636640.

SubP-saponite organoclays based on quaternized SubPs 391 and 393 have been studied in terms of their luminescence properties.624 In addition, a photochemical reaction system, using a metalloporphyrin as a photocatalyst and quaternized SubP 393 as a photoantenna, has been constructed on a clay nanosheet as an artificial photosynthetic model. Efficient energy transfer from the SubP to the metalloporphyrin of up to 98% was achieved. Such dyeclay complexes have proven to photocatalyze the conversion of cyclohexene using a wide range of visible region without any energy loss.577

In another example, a dye-sensitised photoanode for visible light-driven water oxidation to O2 has been constructed using the pushpull SubP 636 (Fig. 121). The dye has been integrated as the photosensitizer in a photoelectrochemical cell with a TiO2 electrode, together with [RuII(bda)(pic)2] (bda = 2,2-bipyridine-6,6-dicarboxylic acid, pic = 4-picoline), which works as the water oxidation catalyst.578 Structurally referable pushpull SubPs 637640 were investigated as photosensitizers in DSSCs achieving power conversion efficiencies (PCE) of 6.010.1.576

6.6 Subporphyrin analogues

6.6.1 Borenium cations. Borenium cations (SubP)B+ (Fig. 122) are always detected in positive ion mass spectrometry of boron SubPs and constitute feasible intermediates in axial ligand exchange reactions under acidic conditions.640 Their spectroscopic properties have been reviewed by some of us.1 The SubP borenium cations were isolated by Osuka and co-workers as stable carborane salts (see for example 641 in Fig. 122) in 5891% yield by treating the corresponding SubP derivatives with Et3Si[CH6B11Br6].640 The crystal structure of the borenium cations is almost planar (bowl-depth of 0.114 ) with BN bond lengths significantly shorter than for the neutral species, reflecting the positive charge and the hybridization change of the central boron from sp3 to sp2.
Fig. 122 Structures of borenium cation (SubP)B+ as carborane anion salt and bacteriochlorines.
6.6.2 Modifications on the subporphyrin pyrrole rings. A3-type subchlorins 642644 (Scheme 58) have been prepared by Osuka and co-workers by reduction of the quasi-isolated pyrrolic double bond of the parallel SubPs 390, 399, 407 with p-tosylhydrazide (method A) (Table 27).587 The use of NiRa, affords the corresponding subbacteriochlorins 649652 (Fig. 122), which are obtained with comparable yields of 2147%.660 Panda and co-workers have prepared A3 (648) and A2B-subchlorins (645647) in 611% yields directly from the complexation of the tripyrrane f wherein R1 constitute ester groups, followed by reaction with triethyl orthoformate603,661 or acyl chloride derivatives661 under standard conditions for SubP synthesis (Scheme 58 method B) (Table 27).
Scheme 58 Synthesis of chlorins 642648.
Table 27 Methods for the preparation of subchlorins
Subchlorin R1 R2 Methoda Ref.
a Method A: p-tosylhydrazide, K2CO3, pyridine. Method B: R2COCl or CH(OEt)3, 1,2-dichlorobenzene, 100 C.
642 Ph Ph A 587
643 A 587
644 A 587
645 CO2Et H B 603
646 CO2Et Ph B 661
647 CO2Et n-Pr B 661
648 CO2Et CO2Et B 661

Subbacteriochlorins can be oxidized with Ag2O to the corresponding Subchlorins, with higher overall yields than those obtained in the one step procedure with the hydrazide.660 In turn, Subchlorins can also be oxidized to the corresponding SubPs using DDQ.

As SubPs, Subchlorins and Subbacteriochlorins exhibit a 14-electron aromatic circuit and conical geometry, with bowl-depths of 1.26 , although the degree of aromaticity of the three compounds is different, as inferred from their NMR data. Accordingly, the nuclear independent chemical shift (NICS) values calculated at B3LYP/6-311G(d) level are of 10.9 ppm for 649 < 14.9 ppm for 642 < 18.9 ppm for 390.659 The different aromatic characters of the three compounds are also reflected by their optical properties, with decrease and blue shift of the Soret bands in 642 and 649, related to that of 390, while the fluorescence quantum yields follow the order 642 < 390 < 649 (Fig. 123). Comparatively, the oxidation potentials of Subbacteriochlorins are lower than those of the corresponding Subchlorins, and these are in turn lower than those of the parallel SubP. For example, the potential values for the first oxidation peaks are of 0.00 V for 649, 0.42 V for 642 and 0.78 V for 390.587,660


Fig. 123 Comparative spectrum of SubP, subchlorin and subbacteriochlorin. Adapted with permission from ref. 660. Copyright 2011 American Chemical Society.

Pyrrole cleaving modifications have been performed in SubPs giving rise to Subporphyrin analogues with different structural, chemical and electronic properties. Thus, the Subseco-chlorins 656 and 657 have been prepared through controlled monobromination of 574, followed by substitution to give the alcohol 654, which was oxidized to dioxoSubchlorin 655. The latter was transformed into the Subseco-chlorin 656, and subsequently decarboxylated to 657.614 Most importantly, the dioxo- and Subseco-chlorins have been used in a variety of chemical transformations to give different core modified SubP analogues,614 such as subporpholactone 664, subporpholactama 665, imidazoloSubP 666,662 dithiazoloSubchlorin 667, dithiazinoSubchlorin 668, oxodithiazinoSubchlorin 669, dioxodithiazinoSubchlorin 670,663 and quinoxalino-fused SubPs 671674,664 as described in Scheme 59 and Table 28.


Scheme 59 Synthesis of dioxoSubchlorin 655, subseco-chlorins 656 and 657 and their chemical conversions.
Table 28 Chemical modifications of dioxoSubchlorin 655, subseco-chlorins 656 and 657
SubP R1 R2

X Ref.
658 H NO2 614
659 H F 614
660 H Cl 614
661 H 614
662 H 614
663 H 614
664 662
665 662
666 662
667 None 663
668 CH2 663
669 CO 663
670 663

6.6.3 Subpyriporphyrins and [3]cyclo-1,8-carbazolylene. Subpyridoporphyrin 675 represents another type of core-modified SubPs that contains a pyridine ring replacing one of the pyrrole moieties.1,665 Reported by Latos-Grayski before SubPs, it was prepared in 6% yield through monobenzoylation, reduction and intramolecular condensation reactions, starting from a pyrido tripyrrane k (Scheme 60). As a distinctive structural feature, Subpyridoporphyrin is obtained as a free base triphyrin, which can react with PhBCl2 to yield the metal complex 676 where the macrocycle acts as monoanionic tridentate ligand. The coordination leads to aromatization of the macrocycle because of structural changes allowing delocalization of 14 electrons. The electronic spectrum of 675 displays two bands at 346 and 730 nm, respectively, that are parallel to the B and Q-porphyrin absorption bands.666 The changes induced upon metalation are not great, apart from a slight bathochromic shift of the broad Q-band with respect to the free base.
Scheme 60 Synthesis of subpyriporphyrins 675 and 676.

[3]Cyclo-1,8-carbazolylenes 677 and 678 constitute even more exotic tripyrrole-based porphyrinoids that have been prepared in 1116% yields by Higashibayashi and co-workers. The synthetic procedure involves Ni(COD)2-mediated cyclo-oligomerization of 1,8-dibromocarbazole (Scheme 61).667 X-ray analysis revealed a distorted, flake-shaped C2 structure with three chiral axes that possesses axial chirality, the relative configuration of which is expressed as (S*,R*,R*). Free base 678 represents a trivalent tridentate ligand that hosts boron, phosphorus, and silicon atoms (Scheme 61, compounds 679681). The introduction of the different heteroatoms has been achieved by treatment with BBr3, PCl3 or PhSiCl3, respectively, in the presence of a base. In addition, the phosphorus atom of 681 has been oxidized with m-CPBA, leading to the phosphine oxide 682.


Scheme 61 Preparation of [3]cyclo-1,8-carbazolylenes.

X-ray diffraction analysis of the complexes 679, 681 and 682, as well as DFT calculations on 680, revealed a location for the central heteroatoms above the curved surface. The absorption profile of 677682 is dominated by a strong band ( = 3000040000 M1 cm1) at 301317 nm, accompanied by weaker bands ( = 500017000 M1 cm1) at 356415 nm, while their emission bands appear at 421440 nm, with fluorescence quantum yields ranging from 0.06 (681) to 0.34 (680).

6.6.4 [14]Triphyrins(2.1.1). meso-Aryl-substituted [14]triphyrin(2.1.1) and [14]benzotriphyrin(2.1.1) derivatives reported by Shen, Yamada and Kobayashi, represent SubP analogues containing one additional meso-carbon in its structure. The insertion of the second sp2-hybridized carbon atom between one of the three neighboring pairs of pyrroles produces nearly planar, metal-free, contracted porphyrinoids, containing 14 -electron aromatic circuits.668 Synthetic aspects and spectroscopic properties of [14]triphyrins(2.1.1) have been previously reviewed by some of us,1 and others.5,649,669,670

The synthesis of [14]triphyrins(2.1.1) can be performed in one step with 1040% yields, by condensation reaction between a pyrrole n (Scheme 62, method A) and an aryl aldehyde in the presence of high concentration (1.2 equivalents) of BF3OEt2.668 An azafulvene or an azafulvenium cation have been proposed as feasible intermediates of the cyclization reaction to assemble the triphyrin(2.1.1) ring.671 When 3,4-diethylpyrrole is used as the starting material, the corresponding hexaethyl-substituted [14]triphyrin(2.1.1) 683 is obtained (Table 29).672 4,7-Dihydro-4,7-ethano-2H-isoindole (BCOD-pyrrole) provides macrocycle 684 (Table 29), which has been quantitatively transformed into the corresponding [14]tribenzotriphyrin(2.1.1) 685 by retro DielsAlder reaction. Triphyrins 686689 (Table 29) were prepared by a similar RothemundDielsAlder sequence, as well as the analogous [14]trinaphthotriphyrin(2.1.1) 691. Compounds 685, 686, and 688 have been used as efficient catalysts for direct CH arylation of benzene with aryl halides,673 while 687 catalyses the two-electron reduction of O2 by Me8Fc, to produce H2O2.674


Scheme 62 Methods for the synthesis of [14]triphyrin(2.1.1).
Table 29 Synthesis of [14]triphyrins(2.1.1) and [14]tribenzotriphyrins(2.1.1)
Triphyrin Ar1 Ar2 R1 R2 R3 Method Ref.
a Using 4,7-dihydro-4,7-ethano-2H-isoindole (BCOD-pyrrole), followed by retro DielsAlder reaction.
683 Et Et Et A 672
684 Ph Ph A 668 and 672
685 Ph Ph Aa 668 and 672
686 Aa 668 and 672
687 Aa 668 and 672
688 Aa 672
689 Aa 672
690 A 672
691 Aa 672
692 H H CH3 n-Bu Et B 675
693 Ph H H H C 676
694 Ph H H H D 677
695 Ph H H H D 677
696 Ph Ph H H H D 677
697 Ph H H H D 677
698 Ph H H H D 677
699 Ph H H H D 678
700 H H H D 678

Three stepwise procedures have been reported for the synthesis of [14]tribenzotriphyrins(2.1.1). Method B (Scheme 62) consists in the McMurry coupling of the diformyltripyrrane intermediate o, followed by oxidation. The latter has been used to prepare the unsubstituted triphyrin at the meso-positions 692 (Table 29).675 Moreover, the reaction of dipyrroethane-derivative p with an aromatic aldehyde in the presence of TFA (method C, Scheme 62) allowed to prepare the [14]triphyrin(2.1.1) 693 (Table 29) bearing different substitution at the meso-positions.676 The mechanism for method C should involve partial cleavage of the dipyrrole intermediate p or an intermediate evolved from it, and formation of a free pyrrole.676 A most recent [2+1] procedure that allowed to prepare meso-arylated [14]triphyrins(2.1.1) 694700 in 1518% yields (method D) consists in the reduction of acylated dipyrroethene intermediates q (Scheme 62) with NaBH4, leading to the corresponding dipyrroethene-dicarbinol, which is in situ condensed with pyrrole in the presence of trifluoroacetic acid, followed by oxidation with DDQ in open air.677,678 Owing to the availability of the precursors n and q, Methods A and D have general applicability to the synthesis of various symmetric and non-symmetric [14]triphyrins(2.1.1), respectively, while the scope of methods B and C is very much restricted to compounds 691 and 692 so far.

There are very scarce examples on the pyrrole or meso-fabrication of triphyrins. Two ethynyl-ferrocene substituents have been introduced at the two-meso-methylene bridges by Sonogashira coupling reaction.678 Likewise, one of the -pyrrole positions of the tilted pyrrole ring (see crystal structure below) has been selectively monobrominated, and subsequently subjected to Sonogashira coupling with ethynyl-ferrocene.678

The crystal structure of triphyrin 696 reveals the presence of one 1H-pyrrole and two 2H-pyrrole rings, the former attached to the meso-carbon of the ethene bridge and with strong hydrogen-bonding interactions with the two 2H-pyrrole nitrogen atoms. As a consequence, the triphyrin core shows an almost planar arrangement, except for the 2H-pyrrole ring opposite to the ethene bridge, which is slightly tilted (16.6) from the mean plane defined by the four meso-carbons.677 Two of the meso-phenyl substituents display a dihedral angle of 77 each, with respect to the plane of the triphyrin, whereas the corresponding dihedral angles of the other two are of 46.7 and 36.9, respectively. The strong triple hydrogen bonding presumably compensates the macrocycle's diamagnetic ring current effect, therefore, the resonances of the [14]triphyrin(2.1.1) inner NH protons lie at remarkably low field despite their calculated NICS(0) values ranging from 9.15 to 15.6 ppm.668,672,677 Similar structures have been reported for triphyrins 692 and 693.675,676 The crystal structure of the benzo-fused triphyrin 685 also shows 16.3 tilting for the corresponding isoindole ring situated opposite to the ethene bridge. But conversely to the pyrrole series, a rapid exchange between the two NH tautomers is suggested in the solid state.668

The optical spectra of the [14]triphyrin (2.1.1) free bases are dominated by an intense band between 350 and 450 nm and weaker bands in the 500650 nm region (Fig. 124), which have been assigned to allowed and forbidden B and Q bands, respectively, by analogy with Gouterman's four-orbital model for tetrapyrrole porphyrinoids. Thus, for example, tetraphenyl-substituted triphyrin 696 exhibits a B-band at 380 ( = 5012) nm, in addition to three Q-absorptions at 478 (631), 528 (794) and 564 (794) nm.677 Fusing benzene and naphthalene rings to the [14]triphyrin(2.1.1) skeleton produces red shifts both of the B and Q bands, with concomitant increase of the latter (Fig. 124a), as a diagnostic for extended conjugation.672,679 Similar effects are observed in the MCD spectra of the same compounds (Fig. 124b).672


Fig. 124 (a) Comparative electronic absorption spectra of a [14]triphyrin(2.1.1) (690), benzo-fused (687) and naphtho-fused (691) derivatives in toluene. (b) MCD spectra of a [14]triphyrin(2.1.1) (690), benzo-fused (687) and naphtho-fused (691) derivatives in toluene. Adapted with permission from ref. 672. Copyright 2011 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

Some [14]triphyrins(2.1.1) are weakly fluorescent, showing an emission band around 560 nm (695698), or 580 nm (700).676678 The tribenzo- and trinaphtho-series display their emission bands bathochromically shifted at 596 and 628 nm, respectively, with very low quantum yields of 0.01 and 0.04, respectively. Time-resolved fluorescence and fluorescence anisotropy measurements point to a considerable influence of the overall planarity, which is enhanced by the peripheral fused moieties, as the main the factor affecting the excited-state lifetimes,679 excluding any role of internal proton transfer (IPT) in the relaxation of the excited states.680 In fact, molecular distortion, which is produced by meso-substituents and reduced by the inner hydrogen bond, plays a major role in suppressing the non-radiative relaxation.681

The [14]triphyrin (2.1.1) free bases are electrochemically easier to reduce and more difficult to oxidize than the corresponding SubPs. Thus, for comparison, tetrabenzo-triphyrin 696 shows two reversible reductions at 0.84 and 1.25 V (1.13 V more positive than SubP 390) and one irreversible oxidation at 1.32 V (0.61 V anodically shifted with respect to SubP (390).677 As described below, the difference in the redox potentials of the two types of subporphyrinoids triphyrin and SubP arises from the additional meso carbon, rather than from the lack of central boron atom.

[14]Triphyrin(2.1.1) can function as a cyclic, monoanionic, tridentate ligand,669 and coordinate metal ions such as rhenium(I),672,675,677,682 manganese(I),675,683 ruthenium(II),672 or platinum(IV),684 leading to octahedral complexes (Fig. 126b), while rhodium(III) produces square pyramidal conformations,685 and B(III) provides tetrahedral structures (Fig. 125 and Table 30).686 In addition, 5-cyclopentadienyliron(II) and 1,3-C8H12 iridium(III) triphyrin sandwich complexes, in which Fe(II) and Ir(III) are inserted between Cp and COD ligands, respectively, and one triphyrin macrocycle, have been reported.687,688 With the exception of the Pt(IV) complexes, which are obtained upon oxidation of the corresponding Pt(II) complexes, all of the other triphyrin complexes can be prepared by heating a free base with the appropriate metal salt. The resulting complexes are bowl-shaped, with the metal ions lying above the plane containing the three inner nitrogens. The bowl-depth for the rhenium(I) complexes has been reported to range from 2.22.5 , about 1 larger than those of boron(III) SubPs (see Tables 24 and 30). Similar curvature has been observed for Mn(I) complexes, although the reported bowl-depth values are about 0.20.3 shorter than those reported for the Re(I) complexes, and in the same order as that observed for the Rh(III), Ir(III) and Pt(IV) complexes bases (Fig. 126).684,685,688 On the other hand, Fe(II) complexes show a less pronounced curvature (1.8 ),687 and B(III) complexes result to be much flatter, with bowl depths of 0.931.03 , even shorter than that of the parallel SubP 574 (Tables 24 and 30).686


Fig. 125 Metallated [14]triphyrins(2.1.1).

Fig. 126 (a) ORTEP diagrams showing top and side view of 723. Thermal ellipsoids are drawn at 50% probability with the phenyl groups omitted for the side views. (b) ORTEP diagrams showing top and side view of 717. Thermal ellipsoids are drawn at 50% probability with the phenyl groups omitted for the side views. (c) Comparative absorption spectra of 688 (black line), 723 (red line), and 717 (blue line) in CH2Cl2. Adapted with permission from ref. 684. Copyright 2013 American Chemical Society.
Table 30 [14]Triphyrin(2.1.1) metal complexes
Triphyrin Ar1 Ar2 R1 R2 R3 M Bowl-depth () Ref.
701 Re(CO)3 2.248 672
702 H H CH3 n-Bu Et Re(CO)3 2.536 675
703 Ph Ph Re(CO)3 2.201 682
704 Re(CO)3 682
705 Re(CO)3 682
706 Ph H H H Re(CO)3 2.527 677
707 Ru(CO)2Cl 672
708 H H CH3 n-Bu Et Mn(CO)3 2.224 675
709 Ph Ph Mn(CO)3 1.977 683
710 Mn(CO)3 683
711 Mn(CO)3 2.028 683
712 Mn(CO)3 683
713 Ph Ph RhCl2 1.935 685
714 RhCl2 685
715 RhCl2 685
716 RhCl2 685
717 PtCl3 1.988 684
718 H H CH3 n-Bu Et BPh (BF4) 0.93 686
719 Ph Ph BPh (BF4) 1.03 686
720 FeCp 1.772 687
721 FeCp 1.807 687
722 Ph Ph Ir(cod) 2.117 688
723 PtCl2 684
724 PdCl2 689
725 Ph Ph PdCl2 689

[14]Triphyrin (2.1.1) can also function as a neutral bidentate ligand with Pt(II)684 and Pd(II) ions,689 leading to structures like 723725 (Fig. 125 and Table 30) with deep, saddle conformation and Cs symmetry bases (Fig. 126a). The coordination mode for these complexes is square-planar, with cis-conformation for the Pt(II) and Pd(II) ions. Here, the non-coordinated pyrrole rings tilt downward from the mean plane defined by the four meso-carbon atoms, while the two coordinated pyrrole rings are tilted upward (Fig. 126a).

In general, the optical spectra of triphyrin complexes are very similar, with absorption bands in the Q-region that are more extended to the red and infrared regions than those of the corresponding free bases (Fig. 126). The intense bands in the 450550 nm region of the spectra of the metal complexes and the weaker envelopes of absorbance intensity to the red of the Q bands (450800 nm) have been assigned to metal to ligand charge transfer (MLCT) bands on the basis of TD-DFT calculations.672,675,677,687,688 The absorption properties of the boron complexes 718 and 719 are exceptionally more similar to that of the free bases than those of the other metal derivatives.686 Besides, the insertion of the boron atom in 718 and 719 does not bring the corresponding redox potentials near to those of SubPs. On the contrary, the oxidation and reduction features of the boron complexes appear relatively similar to those of the parallel free bases 692 and 696, at 1.38 and 0.83 V for 718 and 1.16, 0.78 and +1.27 V for 719,686 pointing to a little effect of the central boron atom in the electrochemical differences between SubPs and [14]triphyrin (2.1.1). Other central ions such as rhenium(I), produce further anodic shifts on the corresponding oxidation and reduction peaks (for example, 1.12, 0.65 and +1.35 V for 706).677

6.6.5 Other triphyrins. Triphyrin analogues comprise a variety of macrocycles in which one or more pyrrole units of the triphyrin structure have been replaced by carbocycles, like in carbatriphyrins(3.1.1),690 carbatriphyrins(2.1.1) (726Fig. 126),691 azulitriphyrins(1.2.1) (727),692,693 or other types of carbatriphyrins,694 including the triphyrin(2.1.1)-tetraphyrin(1.1.1.1) hybrid 737.695 Substitution of one pyrrole ring by other heterocycles also produces triphyrin analogues. Many of these works have been performed in the laboratories of H. Yamada, M. Pawlicki or Latos-Grayski. For example, replacement by a thiophene ring leads to thiatriphyrins(2.1.1) (728 and 729).696,697 The oxatriphyrin appellative refers to an assortment of structures containing a furan unit, of which [14]oxatriphyrin(2.1.1) (730) constitutes the simpler representative.698 Other oxatriphyrins contain additional rings, like an ortho-phenylene motif (731),699 or a fused benzene ring,697 or a thiophene ring (732, 733),700,701 benzofuran (735) or benzothiophene rings (734),702 as well as dibenzofuran or dibenzothiophene rings.703 An additional furan moiety (736) leads to oxatriphyrin(3.1.1) (Fig. 127).704,705
Fig. 127 Some examples of triphyrin analogues containing carbocycle or heterocycle subunits.

Other modifications consist in the insertion of meso-bridges of different nature between the three triphyrin pyrrole rings. For example, the so-called vacataphyrins 738 (Fig. 128) consist of a [18]triphyrin(6.1.1) structure,706 while triphyrin 739 consists of a [15]triphyrin(1.1.3) derivative.707 [22]Triphyrin(6.6.0) (740) and [22]Triphyrin(6.5.0) (741) represent examples of what has been called expanded porphyrin contraction.708,709 In 742 one of the meso-units consists of an aminoethoxy moiety,710 while [18]triphyrins(4.1.1) containing ethyne (743 and 744)711713 or butadiene714 bridges have been reported. All of these structures contain completely different macrocyclic cores and hence, new and diverse coordination chemistry.669


Fig. 128 Some examples of triphyrin analogues containing different motifs as meso-bridges.

7. Conclusions

Since the serendipitous synthesis of the first subporphyrinoid in 1972, the chemistry of tripyrrole and triisoindole porphyrin analogues has expanded considerably. This review, which comprehensively covers the last decade of discoveries, documents the exponential growth in the number of publications related to subporphyrinoids and highlights the scientific interest in this class of compounds for many application areas ranging from optoelectronics to biomedicine.

On one hand, big steps forward have been made during the last years in the fundamentals of subporphyrinoids chemistry. The development and optimization of novel methodologies for the synthesis and post-functionalization of these contracted macrocycles keep drawing attention, leading to the possibility of finely tuning the optoelectronic properties of these derivatives. Importantly, tremendous progress has been made in understanding the supramolecular organization of these cone-shaped cores. On the other hand, the application of subporphyrinoids is gaining more and more attention from the scientific community due to the outstanding physicochemical characteristics that these macrocycles offer. The field of subporphyrinoid-base systems for solar energy conversion has blossomed during the last decade, paving the way for the effective implementation of these derivatives in photovoltaics. Moreover, significant advances have been made in the exploitation of this contracted porphyrinoids for therapy and imaging in bio-focused application.

Nevertheless, this upward trend is still at an early stage, and many challenging issues at both the fundamental and application levels remain unexplored. The preparation and exploitation of chiral subporphyrinoids constitutes one of the hottest topics in the frame of the optoelectronic applications of these derivatives. Although initial studies on the application of SubPcs in solar energy conversion schemes have shown the great potential of this class of compound, future efforts are needed to optimize the architecture and the performances of SubPc-containing photovoltaic devices. On the other hand, more comprehensive studies are needed in the frame of the biological applications of SubPcs. Certainly, the development of subporphyrinoid-based applications requires further efforts and fundamental progresses in the chemistry of these macrocycles.

We hope that this review, in which the most recent advances in subporphyrinoids are presented and discussed, will inspire and boost further research in this area, contributing to unveil the fundamentals of this fascinating class of compounds, and leading to innovative developments in their known implementations in optoelectronics and biomedicine as well as in yet unexplored applications.

Author contributions

G. L.: coordination, writing original draft, writing review & editing. J. L., M. V. M.-D., and M. S. R.-M.: writing original draft. A. O. and T. T.: conceptualization, supervision and editing.

Conflicts of interest

There are no conflicts to declare.
